snippet: As senator after senator offered more criticism of General Motors, Ms. Barra, G.M.’s chief executive, signaled that there were limits to what the company would do.
abstract: General Motors chief executive Mary T Barra remains firm under bruising criticism during Senate hearing over company's long failure to recall millions of small cars; insists GM will not expand victim compensation program, will not share documents from internal investigation, nor dismiss general counsel Michael P Millikin, as several senators requested; tone signals subtle but important shift as company attempts to emerge from gravest safety crisis in its history.

byline.original: By BILL VLASIC and AARON M. KESSLER
byline.contributor: Rebecca R. Ruiz and Danielle Ivory contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: As senator after senator offered more criticism of General Motors, Ms. Barra, G.M.’s chief executive, signaled that there were limits to what the company would do.

headline.main: At Hearing on G.M. Recall, Mary Barra Gives Little Ground
headline.print_headline: At Senate Hearing, G.M. Chief Gives Little Ground
